graduation_requirements.description: Students must complete 22 total credits with specific requirements in each subject area, maintain a minimum 2.0 GPA, and complete 40 hours of community service.

courses.name: English 9
courses.description: Freshman English focusing on literature, composition, and critical thinking.

courses.name: English 10
courses.description: Sophomore English with emphasis on literary analysis and writing.

courses.name: English 11
courses.description: Junior English covering American literature and research writing.

courses.name: English 12
courses.description: Senior English focusing on British literature and college-level writing.

courses.name: Algebra I
courses.description: Introduction to algebraic concepts and problem-solving.

courses.name: Geometry
courses.description: Study of geometric shapes, proofs, and spatial reasoning.

courses.name: Algebra II
courses.description: Advanced algebraic concepts including functions and equations.

courses.name: AP Calculus AB
courses.description: Advanced Placement Calculus covering limits, derivatives, and integrals.

courses.name: Biology
courses.description: Study of living organisms, cells, and biological systems.

courses.name: Chemistry
courses.description: Introduction to chemical principles and laboratory techniques.

courses.name: Physics
courses.description: Study of motion, forces, energy, and waves.

courses.name: World History
courses.description: Survey of world civilizations and historical events.

courses.name: Government
courses.description: Study of American government and political systems.

counselors.name: Mr. Michael Chen
counselors.specialization: Junior and Senior students, College Planning

attendance.tardies: Students with more than 10 unexcused tardies per semester may face disciplinary action.
attendance.absences: More than 10 excused absences per semester requires a doctor's note or parent meeting.
attendance.makeup_work: Students have 3 days to make up work after an excused absence.

academic.gpa_requirements: Minimum 2.0 GPA required for graduation. Below 2.0 triggers academic intervention.
academic.course_drops: Students may drop a course within the first 2 weeks of the semester with counselor approval.
academic.grade_appeals: Grade appeals must be submitted within 5 days of grade posting.

conduct.plagiarism: Plagiarism results in a zero on the assignment and parent notification.
conduct.cheating: Cheating on exams results in a zero and possible suspension.
conduct.cell_phones: Cell phones must be silenced and put away during class hours.

ap_vs_honors.ap_courses: AP (Advanced Placement) courses are college-level classes that can earn students college credit if they pass the AP exam (score 3+). They are standardized nationwide and look excellent on college applications.
ap_vs_honors.honors_courses: Honors courses are accelerated high school courses that go deeper into material but don't offer college credit. They prepare students well for college-level work and also strengthen applications.
ap_vs_honors.when_to_take: Students should take AP courses in subjects they're strong in and interested in. Start with 1-2 APs in junior year, then add more in senior year if comfortable.
ap_vs_honors.college_credit: AP exam scores of 3, 4, or 5 can earn college credit at most universities, potentially saving time and money.

tips: Maintain a strong GPA throughout high school - colleges look at all four years.
Take challenging courses (AP/Honors) but don't overload yourself.
Get involved in extracurricular activities and leadership roles.
Start building relationships with teachers for recommendation letters.
Begin exploring colleges and majors early (sophomore/junior year).
Take the SAT/ACT seriously and prepare well.
Focus on finding your interests and passions, not just what looks good.
Visit colleges if possible to see if they're a good fit.

testing.sat: SAT is typically taken in junior or senior year. Most colleges accept SAT scores.
testing.act: ACT is an alternative to SAT. Some students perform better on one than the other.
testing.prep: Free prep resources available: Khan Academy (SAT), ACT Academy, and school tutoring programs.
testing.when: Most students take SAT/ACT in spring of junior year and can retake in fall of senior year.
